Introduction

Mold exposure can have varied negative effects on the body.  Molds release spores and toxins (eg, mycotoxins) that can trigger allergic reactions, respiratory illnesses, and, in some cases, severe systemic infections.  Patients with atopy, chronic pulmonary conditions (eg, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease [COPD]), or immunosuppression are at increased risk for mold-related illness.

Pathogenesis



Molds are fungi that thrive in warm, moist environments.  They are ubiquitous in outdoor environments, but mold spores enter indoor spaces through open windows or ventilation systems or by attaching to clothing and shoes.  For many people, mild or occasional mold exposure is not a significant concern.  However, excessive indoor mold growth can be problematic, especially for patients with underlying health conditions such as asthma and immunosuppression.



Mold exposure can cause illness through 3 primary mechanisms:



  • Allergic reactions:  Mold spores act as aeroallergens, triggering IgE-mediated hypersensitivity reactions in susceptible individuals (eg, those with atopy) and leading to allergic rhinitis, allergic asthma, pneumonitis, or dermatitis.
  • Toxic effects:  Certain molds produce mycotoxins that have been linked to a plethora of nonspecific symptoms, including cognitive impairment, mood changes, immune system dysfunction, and even cancer.  However, the causal relationship between mycotoxins and disease is a topic of ongoing research.
  • Infections:  Opportunistic molds can cause serious fungal infections (eg, aspergillosis, mucormycosis) in patients with immunosuppression (eg, stem cell/organ transplant recipients).

Common molds

Aspergillus fumigatus



  • Aspergillus fumigatus may induce mild allergy symptoms (eg, sneezing) in healthy, immunocompetent patients.
  • It can cause allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA), a severe pulmonary hypersensitivity reaction that occurs mainly in patients with asthma and cystic fibrosis (

Mucor and Rhizopus



  • Mainly affect patients who are immunocompromised or have diabetes mellitus.
  • Cause rhino-orbital-cerebral mucormycosis, a rapidly progressive, necrotizing infection of the paranasal sinuses that aggressively invades surrounding structures (eg, orbit, bone, brain) (

  • May cause pulmonary mucormycosis (a necrotizing pneumonia characterized by rapid spread to nearby mediastinal structures), gastrointestinal mucormycosis (causes mucosal ulceration, bleeding, and perforation), and cutaneous mucormycosis (begins with a single site of cellulitis that rapidly becomes necrotic).

Fusarium



  • Fusarium is associated with keratitis (inflammation of the cornea) and onychomycosis (nail fungus) in immunocompetent patients.
  • Patients with immunosuppression can develop disseminated disease involving the sinuses, lungs (eg, bilateral pneumonia), and skin/soft tissues (eg, papular lesions with central necrosis) (
    image 1
    ).

Stachybotrys chartarum (black mold)



  • Produces mycotoxins that can cause respiratory issues (eg, chronic cough, sneezing), eye/skin irritation, fatigue, and, possibly, neuropsychologic symptoms (eg, headache, poor concentration, irritability).

Risk factors

Environmental risk factors



  • Damp indoor environments (eg, water-damaged homes, basements, bathrooms).
  • Occupational exposure (eg, farmers exposed to moldy crops, health care personnel exposed to contaminated equipment).
  • Geographic factors (eg, high-humidity areas, flood-prone regions).

Host-related risk factors



  • Atopy:  Patients with asthma, allergic rhinitis, and eczema have increased susceptibility to mold hypersensitivity reactions.
  • Chronic lung diseases (eg, COPD, cystic fibrosis, bronchiectasis):  Patients with these conditions have impaired mucociliary clearance of inhaled particles, and their airways are more sensitive to irritants.  They may also be more prone to fungal infection due to chronic steroid use and structural lung changes.
  • Immunocompromised states (eg, HIV/AIDS, chemotherapy, organ/stem cell transplantation, chronic steroid use):  Patients who are immunocompromised have a reduced ability to clear their airways of pathogens and control the spread of infection.
  • Infants and elderly patients:  These patients have weaker immune defenses.

Clinical presentation

Allergic reactions



Allergic reactions are more common in patients with atopy, but healthy persons can also be affected.  Symptoms related to mold exposure typically occur over an extended time without a clear etiology:



  • Allergic rhinitis:  Sneezing, nasal congestion, runny nose, itchy eyes.
  • Allergic asthma:  Coughing, wheezing, dyspnea, frequent exacerbations.
  • Hypersensitivity pneumonitis:  An immune reaction within the lung tissue that causes chest tightness, shortness of breath, cough, fever, and myalgia.
  • Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA):  Frequent asthma exacerbations, fever, fatigue, brown mucus, mucus plugging, and, occasionally, hemoptysis.

Mycotoxin-related symptoms



"Toxic mold syndrome" is a term used to describe the variable effects that mycotoxins can have on the body.  The exact relationship between mycotoxin exposure and symptomatology is still under evaluation, but findings may include:



  • Respiratory symptoms:  Cough, wheezing, chest tightness occur.
  • Neuropsychologic symptoms:  Headaches, dizziness, difficulty concentrating, memory impairment ("brain fog"), anxiety, and depression can also occur.
  • Immune system changes:  Mycotoxin exposure may alter immune responses to some antigens.
  • Cancer:  Several mycotoxins have been identified as carcinogens.

Invasive mold infections



Invasive infections are observed mainly in patients with immunosuppression or chronic lung disease.



  • Invasive pulmonary aspergillosis:  Cough, pleuritic chest pain, hemoptysis, fever, and nodular and/or cavitary lung lesions on chest x-ray.
  • Invasive fungal rhinosinusitis (eg, mucormycosis):  Nasal congestion, purulent discharge, fever, headache/facial pain, periorbital edema, and black eschar on the palatal mucosa or nasal turbinates.
  • Fungemia/disseminated infections:  Persistent fever unresponsive to antibiotics, and multiorgan involvement (eg, endophthalmitis, meningitis).  Disseminated mold infections have a very poor prognosis.

Diagnosis



Diagnosing a mold-related illness can be challenging because the symptoms overlap with many other respiratory and infectious conditions.

History and physical examination



  • Assess for environmental exposures such as visible mold, musty odor, recent flooding, or unrepaired leaks at home or work.
  • Determine the onset, duration, and progression of symptoms.  Subacute and chronic symptoms (without an obvious cause) triggered in specific environments are suspicious for mold illness.
  • Identify preexisting conditions that may increase susceptibility to mold-related illness (eg, asthma, eczema, immunosuppression).
  • Evaluate for allergic or toxic mold symptoms (eg, watery eyes, nasal edema, wheezing, frequent asthma exacerbations, respiratory symptoms with associated neuropsychologic changes).
  • Look for evidence of invasive fungal disease (eg, prolonged fever unresponsive to antibiotics, necrotic nasal lesions, severe pneumonia).

Laboratory evaluation



Laboratory testing for mold-related illnesses may include:



  • Allergy skin tests:  A small amount of an allergen is introduced into the skin to determine reactivity to specific molds.
  • Complete blood count and IgE antibody tests:  Elevated eosinophils and total IgE levels are common in patients with mold allergies, although these findings are nonspecific and observed in most types of allergic responses.  Eosinophilia with Aspergillus-specific IgG and IgE antibodies are indicative of ABPA.
  • Fungal cultures grown from sputum, nasal, or tissue samples:  These cultures identify the specific fungal species (eg, Aspergillus, Mucor, Rhizopus).
  • Beta-D-glucan assay and galactomannan biomarkers:  Beta-D-glucan and galactomannan are constituents of Aspergillus fungal cell walls and are used clinically as adjunctive tests to diagnose invasive aspergillosis.
  • Histopathologic evaluation of tissue (eg, lung, sinuses):  Microscopic examination of biopsied tissues shows eosinophils and fungal hyphae (
    image 2
    ).  Specific molds may be identified by their histologic appearance.

Imaging studies



Imaging studies are performed based on the patient's presenting symptoms and are particularly useful when Aspergillus- or Mucor/Rhizopus-related illness is suspected.



  • X-ray or CT scan of the chest to detect fungal pneumonitis/pneumonia:  ABPA presents with fleeting alveolar opacities, branching opacities due to mucoid obstruction, bronchiectasis, and atelectasis, typically in the upper or middle lobes (
    image 3
    ).  Invasive pulmonary aspergillosis causes cavitary lesions with air-fluid levels, airspace consolidation, and nodular infiltrates with surrounding ground-glass opacities (halo sign).
  • CT imaging of the brain and paranasal sinuses for suspected fungal rhinosinusitis:  CT scan identifies bony destruction, sinus opacification, and, occasionally, extension of infection into the orbit or brain.
  • MRI for fungal rhinosinusitis:  MRI provides superior soft tissue resolution and is particularly useful for evaluating intracranial or periorbital extension of fungal rhinosinusitis.

Management

Avoidance and environmental control



Eliminating mold growth and avoiding ongoing exposure are the initial steps in managing mold-related illness.



  • Identify and remove indoor mold sources (eg, carpeting, wallpaper); fix leaks/water damage and ensure adequate ventilation to damp areas.
  • Maintain a dry environment using air conditioners and dehumidifiers, and use high-efficiency particulate air filters to limit indoor spore exposure.  Regularly clean heating, ventilation, and air conditioning systems to prevent mold buildup.
  • Wear protective equipment (masks, gloves) for occupational exposures (eg, farmers).

Mold hypersensitivity reaction



Pharmacologic interventions for allergic/hypersensitivity reactions include antihistamines (eg, loratadine, cetirizine), nasal corticosteroids (eg, fluticasone, budesonide), and inhaled corticosteroids and bronchodilators (for bronchospasm/asthma control).  Allergen immunotherapy (allergy shots) may be used for long-term desensitization.

Mycotoxin-related illness



Mycotoxin-related illness cannot be managed using antifungal medications; therefore, treatment includes avoidance of exposure and symptom management (eg, anti-inflammatory medications for headaches).

Invasive fungal infection



Invasive fungal infections typically require intensive care and aggressive antifungal treatment to prevent morbidity and mortality.



  • Voriconazole for invasive aspergillosis or fusariosis.
  • Amphotericin B and surgical debridement for mucormycosis.


Antifungal prophylaxis should be considered for patients after high-risk transplants.

Summary



Mold exposure can cause negative health effects ranging from mild respiratory irritation to life-threatening invasive fungal infections.  A diagnosis of mold-related illness can be challenging; evaluation requires a thorough assessment for potential mold exposures, predisposing comorbid conditions, and characteristic symptomatology.  Management includes avoiding exposure, managing allergy symptoms, and providing aggressive antifungal medications for invasive or disseminated disease.
